div.head: CERTAINE RVLES, DIRECTIONS, OR ADVERTISEMENTS FOR THIS TIME OF PESTILENTIALL CONTAGION.
div.p:
THe Plague (if you will have his true Characteri≈øme and e≈ø≈øentiall forme) is Ictus irae divinae pro peccatis hominum, Exod. 5. v. 3. & Cap. 9.15. Levit. 26.25. Num. 14.12. Deut. 28.21. & 2 Chron. 36. v. 15. Inter Eth. Homerus 2 Iliad. The ≈øtroke of Gods wrath for the ≈øinnes of mankinde. This is not onely the opinion of Divines, but of all learned Phy≈øitians, and acknowledged by the blinde Heathen in all ages, by the light of nature. Therefore his appropriate and ≈øpeciall Antidote is Seria paenitentia, & conver≈øio ad Deum: unfained and heartie repentance and conver≈øion to God. Till this be practi≈øed, I tell you plainely, I put ≈ømall confidence in other by-cour≈øes. The cau≈øe remaining, who can looke for the taking away of the effect? Let me therefore be an humble ≈øuitor, that your Highne≈ø≈øe would be plea≈øed to command a generall humiliation of the people by prayer and fa≈øting. This action as it would be honourable to your Maje≈øtie, and ≈øuch as you would undoubtedly condi≈øcend unto mo≈øt readily and willingly, if it were but mentioned and moved; ≈øo in my per≈øwa≈øion, there would appeare a mo≈øt admirable and comfortable
effect thereof. And till this be performed, what other wayes ≈øoever wee ≈øhall follow, wee ≈øhall begin at the wrong end:
Ni Deus affuerit, vire≈øque infuderit Herbis,
Quid ced√≤ Diptam√∫s, quid Panacea juvat? Let not Gentlemen and rich Citizens by flying (unle≈ø≈øe they likewi≈øe flie from their ≈øinnes) thinke to e≈øcape Scotfree. So long as they carry their ≈øinne with them, the Lord will find them out, and his hand will reach them where≈øoever they are.

There ≈øhould (in my opinion) be provided a place of Sepulture for the bodies e≈øpecially of ≈øuch as die by the Sicknes, ≈øome good di≈øtance from the Citie and Suburbs. The burying of infected bodies in Churches, Church-yards, and namely in Paules Church-yard, where the chiefe Magi≈øtrates of the Citie, and many other Citizens meete weekly to heare Sermons, mu≈øt needs be not onely inconvenient, but very dangerous for ≈øpreading the contagion, and poi≈øoning the whole Citie. For all men that have the lea≈øt in≈øight in Philo≈øophy know, that from the dead corps, by force of the Sunne, certaine vapours or exhalations are elevated, which partake of the nature of tho≈øe bodies, and doe undoubtedly taint, corrupt, and poy≈øon the aire with their ill qualitie. For this principall cau≈øe, in mo≈øt well ordered Cities of forrein Countries, there is a common place of Buriall appointed a good di≈øtance from the building of the Citie. And till this may be procured for our Citie, I wi≈øh that ≈øtraight charge be given, that
all dead corp≈øes be layd a convenient depth in the ground, and not one coffin heaped upon another, and they layd ≈øo neare the top of the earth as (it is to be feared) they now are.
It were nece≈ø≈øarie the place of Buriall ≈øhould be on the South ≈øide of the Citie, that the Sunne may draw the vapours from it.

Let care be had, that the ≈øtreets, e≈øpecially the narrow lanes and allies, be kept from annoyance of dung-hilles, vaults or hou≈øes of office, the common ≈øewers and chanels be well purged and ≈øcowred, the dung-farmers tyed to their ≈øtint of time in Winter, and not ≈øuffered (unle≈ø≈øe urgent nece≈ø≈øitie require) to perfume the ≈øtreets all Summer long, e≈øpecially in this time of contagion. Let not the carka≈ø≈øes of hor≈øes, dogs, cats, &c. lye rotting and poy≈øoning the ayre (as they have done) in More and Finsburie fields, and el≈øewhere round about the Citie.
Let the Pipes layd from the new River be often opened, to clen≈øe the channels of every ≈øtreete in the Citie.

Let the Ditches towards the ≈øuburbs, e≈øpecially towards I≈ølington and Pick-hatch, Old-≈øtreete, and towards Shoreditch and White-chappell, be well clen≈øed, and if it might be, the water of the new River to runne through them, as al≈øo the like to be done through the Burrough of South-worke.

Let the ayre be purged and corrected, e≈øpecially in evenings which are ≈øomewhat cold, and in places low and neare the River (as Thames ≈øtreet and the Allyes there about) by making fires of Oken or A≈øhwood, with ≈øome few bundles of Iuniper ca≈øt into them.

Let men in their private hou≈øes, amend the aire by laying in their windowes ≈øweet herbes, as Marjoram, Time,Let them likewi≈øe rub their windowes often with worm wood and fennell. Ro≈øemarie, Balme, Fennell, Peniroyall, Mints, &c. Likewi≈øe by burning Iuniper, Ro≈øemarie, Time, Bay-leaves, Cloves, Cinamon, or u≈øing other compound perfumes. The poorer ≈øort may burne Worme-wood, Rue, Time. Let them ca≈øt often on the floores of their hou≈øes water mingled with Vineger.

Concour≈øe of people to Stage-playes, Wakes or Fea≈øts, and May-pole dauncings, are to be prohibited by publique Authoritie, whereby as God is di≈øhonored, the bodies of men and women by ≈øurfetting, drunkennes, and other riots and exce≈ø≈øes, di≈øpo≈øed to infection, and the contagion dangerou≈øly ≈øcattered both in Citie and Countrie.
Let the Bells in Cities and Townes be rung often, and the great Ordnance di≈øcharged, thereby the aire is purified.

Touching our regiment and diet, repletion and inanition (as two dangerous extremities) are heedfully to be avoyded. Tho≈øe meats are to be u≈øed which are of ea≈øie dige≈øtion and apt to breed good juice.

The blankets, matre≈ø≈øes, flockbeds, and all bedclothes of the infected, are to be burned, al≈øo leather garments, becau≈øe they hold the infection very long. Alexander Benedictus reports,Hi≈øt. de Pe≈øt. That in Venice, a flockbed u≈øed in a contagious time, was after 7 yeares found in an inward roome, the Mi≈øtris of the hou≈øe commanded the ≈øervants to ayre and beat it, whereupon the ≈øervants were in≈øtantly infected with the pe≈øtilence and died.

Such as are of hard concoction, and cau≈øe ob≈øtructions, are to be avoyded: ≈øpecially tho≈øe that ea≈øily corrupt and putrifie in the ≈øtomacke, as the mo≈øt part of ≈øummer fruit, raw cherries, plums, apples, &c.

It is not good to be abroad in the ayre, early in the morning before the Sunne have purified the ayre, or late in the night after Sunne-≈øetting. In rainie, darke, and cloudie weather, keepe your hou≈øe as much as you can.

E≈øchue all perturbations of minde, e≈øpecially anger and feare. The one by heating the body opens a doore for the enemie to enter: the other by cowardly running away gives him encouragement to tread on the hedge, which lyeth lowe≈øt, and maketh lea≈øt re≈øi≈øtance.

Let your exerci≈øe be moderate, ad ruborem, non ad ≈øudorem. The time of exerci≈øe is an houre before dinner or ≈øupper, not in the heat of the day, or when the ≈øtomacke is full. V≈øe ≈øeldome familiaritie with Venus, for ≈øhee enfeebleth the body, and maketh it more obnoxious to externall injuries.

You may feede three times in the day,Varietie of meats is pernicious; much more varietie of ≈øauces. but more ≈øparingly than at other times. Shunne varietie of di≈øhes at one meale: Pernicio≈øa ciborum varietas, pernicio≈øior condimentorum. And if at any time the Rule holdeth, The mo≈øt ≈øimple feeding is the mo≈øt whol≈øome feeding; then it is in force at this time of infection. Augenius (a learned Phy≈øitian) thinketh it not po≈ø≈øible that hee that liveth temperately and ≈øoberly, ≈øhould be ≈øubject to the Sickne≈ø≈øe.

Goe not forth of your hou≈øe into the ayre, neither willingly ≈øpeake with any, till you have broken your Fa≈øt. For breakfa≈øt you may u≈øe a good draught of wormwood beere or ale, and a few mor≈øels of bread and butter with the leaves of ≈øage, or el≈øe a to≈øte with ≈øweet ≈øalade oyle, two or three drops of ro≈øe vinegar, and a little ≈øugar. They that have cold ≈øtomackes may drinke a draught of wormewoodwine or malm-≈øey, in ≈øtead of ale or beere. But take heed (as you loue your life) of extreame hot waters, as Aqua vitae, Ro≈øa ≈øolis, or other compound waters of like nature, which Emperickes prepare and ≈øet out with vaine and boa≈øting words: Laudat venales qui vult extrudere merces. Of them Crato a great and learned Phy≈øitian pronounceth, that they were inventa ad jugulandos, non ad curandos homines: devi≈øed to kill not to cure men. Hee ≈øpeaketh of the daily and continuall u≈øe of them: and that is it which I di≈øallow.

If you be not accu≈øtomed to a breakfa≈øt, take the quantitie of a Nutmeg or thereabouts of ≈øome cordiall Electuarie pre≈øcribed by the learned Phy≈øitian, before you ≈øet foot out of doores. If you will u≈øe both, for greater cautell, then take your Electuarie early in the morning, two houres before your breakfa≈øt.
As you walke in the ≈øtreets or talke with any, hold in your mouth a Clove, a peece of a Zodoarie, Angelica, or Enula campana roote.

Once in foure or five dayes take three or foure cordiall and ≈øtomachicall pilles by direction of
your Phy≈øitian, to fortifie the heart and ≈øtomacke again≈øt all corruption, and to clean≈øe your body from ≈øuch humours as may di≈øpo≈øe you to the ≈øickne≈ø≈øe. For Agens non agit ni≈øi in Patiente di≈øpo≈øito: An Agent worketh not but upon a fitted and di≈øpo≈øed Patient.

If any man be bound by Religion, con≈øanguinitie, office, or any ≈øuch re≈øpect to vi≈øite the ≈øicke parties; let him fir≈øt provide, that the chamber bee well perfumed with odoriferous trochiskes, or ≈øuch like, the windowes layd with the herbes afore-named, the floore cleane ≈øwept, and ≈øprinkled with ro≈øe-water and vineger: that there be a fire of ≈øweet wood burning in the chimney, the windowes being ≈øhut for an houre, then open the ca≈øements towardes the North. Then let him wa≈øh his face and hands with ro≈øe-water and ro≈øe-vineger, and enter into the chamber with a waxe candle in the one hand, and a ≈øponge with ro≈øe-vineger and wormewood, or ≈øome other Pomander, to ≈ømell unto. Let him hold in his mouth a peece of Ma≈øtic, Cinamon, Zedoarie, or Citron pill, or a Clove. Let him de≈øire his ≈øicke friend to ≈øpeake with his face turned from him.

When he goeth forth, let him wa≈øh his hands and face with ro≈øe-vineger and water as before, e≈øpecially if he have taken his friend by the hand as the manner is: and going pre≈øently to his owne hou≈øe, let him change his garments, and lay tho≈øe wherein he vi≈øited his friend, apart for a good time before he re≈øume them againe.
Let him not forget upon his returne home or before, to take a convenient quantitie of his cordiall Electuarie, and forbeare meat an houre or two after it.

div.head: That Amulets confected of Ar≈øenicke, are no good Pre≈øervatives again≈øt the Plague.
div.p: PErceiving many in this Citie to weare about their necks, upon the region of the heart, certaine Placents, or Amulets (as Pre≈øervatives again≈øt the Pe≈øtilence) confected of Ar≈øenicke a ≈øtrong poy≈øon, I have thought it needfull (other men keeping ≈øilence) to declare briefly my opinion touching the ≈øaid Amulets: not (I profe≈ø≈øe) in hatred to any mans per≈øon, or envie at their commoditie, wherein I might have ≈øhared with them, if I could have brought my judgement to concurre with theirs; but in con≈øcience, and di≈øcharge of my dutie. The rather becau≈øe I feare greatly, that through vaine confidence in them, other more appo≈øite, convenient and effectuall Antidotes, and Alexeteries are neglected.

My opinion is, that the≈øe Placents of Ar≈øenicke carried about upon the Region of the heart, are ≈øo farre from effecting any good in that kinde, as a pre≈øervative, that they are very dangerous and hurtfull, if not pernicious to tho≈øe that weare them.

It is evident that Ar≈øenicke being a confe≈ø≈øed poi≈øon, is an oppo≈øite,Gal. 3. de Temp cap. profe≈ø≈øed and perpetuall enemy to our nature. Therefore being worne next the skin, as ≈øoone as the heart waxeth hot by any vehement motion, labour or ≈øtirring (as it falleth out u≈øually) it mu≈øt needs ≈øend out venomous vapours to that noble and principall part; which will either penetrate by their owne force, or be drawne in with the aire by the dilation of tho≈øe arteries which are ≈øpread about the skin.

Now the≈øe poi≈øonfull vapours being entred or ≈øucked into the body, when they finde no contrarie poi≈øon with whom to wra≈øtle as with an enemy (for if there were any venom in the body, the partie could not enjoy health: but we intend him to be in health, whom we would pre≈øerve) they mu≈øt needs imprint a malignant venomous qualitie in the ≈øpirits and heart, mo≈øt adver≈øe and pernicious to nature.

If by Galens doctrine,1 Simp. cap. 18. all Alexeteries in a manner, if they be u≈øed ≈øomewhat too liberally, doe greatly offend and weaken our bodies; ≈øhall wee thinke that ranke poi≈øons and Deleteries (≈øuch as Ar≈øenicke is) if they be ≈øo applied, as to penetrate into the noble≈øt region of all other, will nothing at all violate, and wa≈øt our native, vitall, and radicall heate?

Galen and the ancient Fathers and Ma≈øters of Phy≈øicke,Lib. de Ther. and Pamphil. Epid com. 5. Actius lib. 1. Tetrah. 4 ca. 96. Paulus lib. 2. cap. 35. did not u≈øe to pre≈øerve from the Plague or any other poi≈øon, either by giving another poi≈øon inwardly, or by appointing other poi≈øons to be outwardly applied, but proceeded altogether by
Antidotes and Alexiteries. Lib. de Theriaca ad Pi≈ø. cap. 16. Therefore unle≈ø≈øe wee will di≈øclaime the≈øe ancient worthies and ring-leaders method, and follow new-found and un≈øound devi≈øes, wee mu≈øt fight again≈øt this mon≈øter, not with poi≈øons, but Antidotes.

Gal 6. in Epid.Poi≈øons are defined to be ≈øuch: as at no time doe agree with nature, either well, or ill affected. For though there be poi≈øons which if they finde a contrarie venom in the body, doe fight ≈øo with it, that by the skirmi≈øh both poi≈øons die, and the partie by their contention and colluctation e≈øcapeth with his life: yet it is agreed on by all, that where they finde no ≈øuch adver≈øary or oppo≈øition, they ≈øpeed the partie. Therefore Ar≈øenicke worne by a man in health, finding not onely no contrary poy≈øon to warre upon, but no poy≈øon at all, mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily oppo≈øe and ≈øet upon nature her ≈øelfe.

Lib. 2. de feb. contag. cap. 17. Gerardus Columbus a learned Phy≈øitian reporteth, that it hath beene ob≈øerved, that the wearers of the≈øe Amulets, upon heating their bodies, have fallen into ≈øodaine Lypothimies and ≈øoounings, with other fearefull accidents, which cea≈øed not till the Bagge or Placent was remooved: That others, though not in≈øtantly, yet after ≈øome time, have by late and woefull experience di≈øcerned their malignitie, falling into malignate and pe≈øtilent feavers, ≈øome of them ending with death it ≈øelfe.

Franc. Alphanus a Phy≈øitian of Salerne telleth of one, who wearing Ar≈øenicke, and heating him≈øelfe
at tenni≈øe, fell downe ≈øodainly dead.

Matheus He≈ø≈øus writeth thus: As cordiall bagges or Amulets cannot be di≈øallowed, ≈øo empoi≈øoned can no way bee commended; neither doe I remember that any ever received good from them who ab≈øtained from other Antidotes. This I certainly know, that diver≈øe who carrie about them quick-≈øilver in a nut-≈øhell, by the vaine per≈øwa≈øion of ≈øome impo≈øtors, have died of the Plague: and the coun≈øellers of ≈øuch like Amulets have beene the fir≈øt that have betaken them≈øelves to their heeles, tru≈øting more in their running than cunning. And yet the≈øe good fellowes, per≈øwaded the ignorant with great words, and it may be oaths, that who≈øoever carried Quick-≈øilver or Ar≈øenicke about his necke, was as ≈øafe as if hee had purcha≈øed a protection from the King of heaven.
Hi≈øtorians report, that Caracalla though a wicked Emperour, made a publike Edict or Proclamation, that no man ≈øhould weare about him ≈øuper≈øtitious Amulets.
Theophrastus the great, e≈øteemed (not without cau≈øe) Pericles to have a cra≈øed braine, becau≈øe he ≈øaw him weare an Amulet about his necke.
